Questions.Text: Given an input string, reverse the string word by word. A word is defined as a sequence of non-space characters.
Questions.Name: Reverse Words in a String

Questions.Text: Evaluate the value of an arithmetic expression in Reverse Polish Notation. Valid operators are +, -, *, /. Each operand may be an integer or another expression. For example:
Questions.Name: Evaluate Reverse Polish Notation (Stack)

Questions.Text: Given two strings s and t, determine if they are isomorphic. Two strings are isomorphic if the characters in s can be replaced to get t.
Questions.Name: Isomorphic Strings

Questions.Text: Given two words (start and end), and a dictionary, find the length of shortest transformation sequence from start to end, such that only one letter can be changed at a time and each intermediate word must exist in the dictionary. For example, given:
Questions.Name: Word Ladder (BFS)

Questions.Text: Given two words (start and end), and a dictionary, find all shortest transformation sequence(s) from start to end, such that: 1) Only one letter can be changed at a time, 2) Each intermediate word must exist in the dictionary.
Questions.Name: Word Ladder II (BFS)

Questions.Text: Java Solution 1
Questions.Name: Median of Two Sorted Arrays

Questions.Text: Find the kth largest element in an unsorted array. Note that it is the kth largest element in the sorted order, not the kth distinct element.
Questions.Name: Kth Largest Element in an Array

Questions.Text: Implement wildcard pattern matching with support for '?' and '*'.
Questions.Name: Wildcard Matching

Questions.Text: Implement regular expression matching with support for '.' and '*'.
Questions.Name: Regular Expression Matching

Questions.Name: Merge Intervals

Questions.Text: Given an array of integers, find two numbers such that they add up to a specific target number.
Questions.Name: Two Sum

Questions.Text: This problem is similar to Two Sum.
Questions.Name: Two Sum II

Questions.Text: Design and implement a TwoSum class. It should support the following operations: add and find.
Questions.Name: Two Sum III

Questions.Text: Problem:
Questions.Name: um

Questions.Text: Given an array S of n integers, are there elements a, b, c, and d in S such that a + b + c + d = target? Find all unique quadruplets in the array which gives the sum of target.
Questions.Name: um

Questions.Text: Given an array S of n integers, find three integers in S such that the sum is closest to a given number, target. Return the sum of the three integers. You may assume that each input would have exactly one solution.
Questions.Name: 3Sum Closest

Questions.Text: Implement atoi to convert a string to an integer.
Questions.Name: String to Integer

Note:
You may assume that A has enough space to hold additional elements from B. The number of elements initialized in A and B are m and n respectively.
Questions.Name: Merge Sorted Array

Questions.Text: Analysis
Questions.Name: Valid Parentheses

Questions.Text: Given a string containing just the characters '(' and ')', find the length of the longest valid (well-formed) parentheses substring.
Questions.Name: Longest Valid Parentheses

Questions.Text: Problem:
Questions.Name: Implement strStr()

Questions.Text: Given an array of n positive integers and a positive integer s, find the minimal length of a subarray of which the sum ≥ s. If there isn't one, return 0 instead.
Questions.Name: Minimum Size Subarray Sum

Questions.Text: Given a sorted array and a target value, return the index if the target is found. If not, return the index where it would be if it were inserted in order. You may assume no duplicates in the array.
Questions.Name: Search Insert Position

Questions.Text: Given an unsorted array of integers, find the length of the longest consecutive elements sequence.
Questions.Name: Longest Consecutive Sequence

Questions.Text: Given a string, determine if it is a palindrome, considering only alphanumeric characters and ignoring cases.
Questions.Name: Valid Palindrome

Questions.Text: The string "PAYPALISHIRING" is written in a zigzag pattern on a given number of rows like this: (you may want to display this pattern in a fixed font for better legibility)
Questions.Name: ZigZag Conversion

Questions.Text: Given two binary strings, return their sum (also a binary string).
Questions.Name: Add Binary

Questions.Text: Given a string s consists of upper/lower-case alphabets and empty space characters ' ', return the length of last word in the string. If the last word does not exist, return 0.
Questions.Name: Length of Last Word

Questions.Text: Given a triangle, find the minimum path sum from top to bottom. Each step you may move to adjacent numbers on the row below.
Questions.Name: Triangle

Questions.Text: Given an array of integers, find if the array contains any duplicates. Your function should return true if any value appears at least twice in the array, and it should return false if every element is distinct.
Questions.Name: I

Questions.Text: Given an array of integers and an integer k, return true if and only if there are two distinct indices i and j in the array such that nums[i] = nums[j] and the difference between i and j is at most k.
Questions.Name: II

Questions.Text: Given an array of integers, find out whether there are two distinct indices i and j in the array such that the difference between nums[i] and nums[j] is at most t and the difference between i and j is at most k.
Questions.Name: III

Questions.Text: Given a sorted array, remove the duplicates in place such that each element appear only once and return the new length. Do not allocate extra space for another array, you must do this in place with constant memory.
Questions.Name: I

Questions.Text: Follow up for "Remove Duplicates": What if duplicates are allowed at most twice?
Questions.Name: II

Questions.Text: Given an array and a value, remove all instances of that value in place and return the new length. (Note: The order of elements can be changed. It doesn't matter what you leave beyond the new length.)
Questions.Name: Remove Element

Questions.Text: Given an array nums, write a function to move all 0's to the end of it while maintaining the relative order of the non-zero elements.
Questions.Name: Move Zeroes

Questions.Text: Given a string, find the length of the longest substring without repeating characters. For example, the longest substring without repeating letters for "abcabcbb" is "abc", which the length is 3. For "bbbbb" the longest substring is "b", with the length of 1.
Questions.Name: Longest Substring Without Repeating Characters

Questions.Text: This is a problem asked by Google.
Questions.Name: Longest Substring that contains 2 unique characters

Questions.Text: You are given a string, s, and a list of words, words, that are all of the same length. Find all starting indices of substring(s) in s that is a concatenation of each word in words exactly once and without any intervening characters.
Questions.Name: Substring with Concatenation of All Words

Questions.Text: Given a string S and a string T, find the minimum window in S which will contain all the characters in T in complexity O(n).
Questions.Name: Minimum Window Substring

Questions.Text: Given an input string, reverse the string word by word.
Questions.Name: Reverse Words in a String

Questions.Text: Suppose a sorted array is rotated at some pivot unknown to you beforehand. (i.e., 0 1 2 4 5 6 7 might become 4 5 6 7 0 1 2).
Questions.Name: I

Questions.Text: Problem
Questions.Name: II

Questions.Text: Suppose a sorted array is rotated at some pivot unknown to you beforehand. (i.e., 0 1 2 4 5 6 7 might become 4 5 6 7 0 1 2).
Questions.Name: I

Questions.Text: Follow up for "Search in Rotated Sorted Array": what if duplicates are allowed? Write a function to determine if a given target is in the array.
Questions.Name: II

Questions.Text: Design a stack that supports push, pop, top, and retrieving the minimum element in constant time.
Questions.Name: Min Stack

Questions.Text: Given an array of size n, find the majority element. The majority element is the element that appears more than ⌊ n/2 ⌋ times. (assume that the array is non-empty and the majority element always exist in the array.)
Questions.Name: I

Questions.Text: Given an integer array of size n, find all elements that appear more than ⌊ n/3 ⌋ times. The algorithm should run in linear time and in O(1) space.
Questions.Name: II

Questions.Text: You are playing the following Bulls and Cows game with your friend: You write down a number and ask your friend to guess what the number is. Each time your friend makes a guess, you provide a hint that indicates how many digits in said guess match your secret number exactly in both digit and position (called "bulls") and how many digits match the secret number but locate in the wrong position (called "cows"). Your friend will use successive guesses and hints to eventually derive the secret number.
Questions.Name: Bulls and Cows

Questions.Text: Given n non-negative integers representing the histogram's bar height where the width of each bar is 1, find the area of largest rectangle in the histogram.
Questions.Name: Largest Rectangle in Histogram

Questions.Text: Problem
Questions.Name: Longest Common Prefix

Questions.Text: Given a list of non negative integers, arrange them such that they form the largest number.
Questions.Name: Largest Number

Questions.Text: Given an absolute path for a file (Unix-style), simplify it.
Questions.Name: Simplify Path

Questions.Text: Problem
Questions.Name: Compare Version Numbers

Questions.Text: There are N gas stations along a circular route, where the amount of gas at station i is gas[i].
Questions.Name: Gas Station

Questions.Text: Given numRows, generate the first numRows of Pascal's triangle. For example, given numRows = 5, the result should be:
Questions.Name: I

Questions.Text: Given an index k, return the kth row of the Pascal's triangle. For example, when k = 3, the row is [1,3,3,1].
Questions.Name: II

Questions.Text: Problem
Questions.Name: Container With Most Water

Questions.Text: There are N children standing in a line. Each child is assigned a rating value. You are giving candies to these children subjected to the following requirements:
Questions.Name: Candy

Questions.Text: Given n non-negative integers representing an elevation map where the width of each bar is 1, compute how much water it is able to trap after raining.
Questions.Name: Trapping Rain Water

Questions.Text: Problem
Questions.Name: Count and Say

Questions.Text: Given a sorted array of integers, find the starting and ending position of a given target value. Your algorithm's runtime complexity must be in the order of O(log n). If the target is not found in the array, return [-1, -1]. For example, given [5, 7, 7, 8, 8, 10] and target value 8, return [3, 4].
Questions.Name: Search for a Range

Questions.Text: Implement a basic calculator to evaluate a simple expression string.
Questions.Name: Basic Calculator

Questions.Text: Given an array of strings, return all groups of strings that are anagrams.
Questions.Name: Group Anagrams

Questions.Text: Given a string S, you are allowed to convert it to a palindrome by adding characters in front of it. Find and return the shortest palindrome you can find by performing this transformation.
Questions.Name: Shortest Palindrome

Questions.Text: Find the total area covered by two rectilinear rectangles in a 2D plane. Each rectangle is defined by its bottom left corner and top right corner coordinates.
Questions.Name: Rectangle Area

Questions.Text: Given a sorted integer array without duplicates, return the summary of its ranges for consecutive numbers.
Questions.Name: Summary Ranges

Questions.Text: Given an unsorted array return whether an increasing subsequence of length 3 exists or not in the array.
Questions.Name: Increasing Triplet Subsequence

Questions.Text: Given a list of numbers and a target number, write a program to determine whether the target number can be calculated by applying "+-*/" operations to the number list? You can assume () is automatically added when necessary.
Questions.Name: Get Target Using Number List And Arithmetic Operations

Questions.Text: Write a function that takes a string as input and reverse only the vowels of a string.
Questions.Name: Reverse Vowels of a String

Questions.Text: You are playing the following Flip Game with your friend: Given a string that contains only these two characters: + and -, you and your friend take turns to flip two consecutive "++" into "--". The game ends when a person can no longer make a move and therefore the other person will be the winner.
Questions.Name: Flip Game

Questions.Text: You are playing the following Flip Game with your friend: Given a string that contains only these two characters: + and -, you and your friend take turns to flip two consecutive "++" into "--". The game ends when a person can no longer make a move and therefore the other person will be the winner.
Questions.Name: Flip Game II

Questions.Text: Given an array containing n distinct numbers taken from 0, 1, 2, ..., n, find the one that is missing from the array. For example, given nums = [0, 1, 3] return 2.
Questions.Name: Missing Number

Questions.Text: Given two strings s and t, write a function to determine if t is an anagram of s.
Questions.Name: Valid Anagram

Questions.Text: Given a string, we can "shift" each of its letter to its successive letter, for example: "abc" -> "bcd". We can keep "shifting" which forms the sequence: "abc" -> "bcd" -> ... -> "xyz".
Questions.Name: Group Shifted Strings

Questions.Text: Given a non-empty array of integers, return the k most frequent elements.
Questions.Name: Top K Frequent Elements

Questions.Text: A peak element is an element that is greater than its neighbors. Given an input array where num[i] ≠ num[i+1], find a peak element and return its index. The array may contain multiple peaks, in that case return the index to any one of the peaks is fine.
Questions.Name: Find Peak Element

Questions.Text: Given a pattern and a string str, find if str follows the same pattern. Here follow means a full match, such that there is a bijection between a letter in pattern and a non-empty word in str.
Questions.Name: Word Pattern

Questions.Text: Given an array of citations (each citation is a non-negative integer) of a researcher, write a function to compute the researcher's h-index. A scientist has index h if h of his/her N papers have at least h citations each, and the other N − h papers have no more than h citations each.
Questions.Name: H-Index

Questions.Text: Given a list of unique words. Find all pairs of distinct indices (i, j) in the given list, so that the concatenation of the two words, i.e. words[i] + words[j] is a palindrome.
Questions.Name: Palindrome Pairs

Questions.Text: Given two strings S and T, determine if they are both one edit distance apart.
Questions.Name: One Edit Distance

Questions.Text: Given two strings s1 and s2 of the same length, determine if s2 is a scrambled string of s1.
Questions.Name: Scramble String

Questions.Text: You are a product manager and currently leading a team to develop a new product. Unfortunately, the latest version of your product fails the quality check. Since each version is developed based on the previous version, all the versions after a bad version are also bad.
Questions.Name: First Bad Version

Questions.Text:
Given a m * n matrix, if an element is 0, set its entire row and column to 0.
Do it in place.
Questions.Name: Set Matrix Zeroes

Questions.Text: Given a matrix of m x n elements (m rows, n columns), return all elements of the matrix in spiral order.
Questions.Name: Spiral Matrix

Questions.Text: Given an integer n, generate a square matrix filled with elements from 1 to n2 in spiral order. For example, given n = 4,
Questions.Name: Spiral Matrix II

Questions.Text: Write an efficient algorithm that searches for a value in an m x n matrix. This matrix has properties:
Questions.Name: Search a 2D Matrix

Questions.Text: Write an efficient algorithm that searches for a value in an m x n matrix. This matrix has the following properties:
Questions.Name: Search a 2D Matrix II

Questions.Text: You are given an n x n 2D matrix representing an image.
Questions.Name: Rotate Image

Questions.Text: Determine if a Sudoku is valid. The Sudoku board could be partially filled, where empty cells are filled with the character '.'.
Questions.Name: Valid Sudoku

Questions.Text: Given a m x n grid filled with non-negative numbers, find a path from top left to bottom right which minimizes the sum of all numbers along its path.
Questions.Name: Minimum Path Sum (DP)

Questions.Text: A robot is located at the top-left corner of a m x n grid. It can only move either down or right at any point in time. The robot is trying to reach the bottom-right corner of the grid.
Questions.Name: Unique Paths (DP)

Questions.Text: Follow up for "Unique Paths":
Questions.Name: Unique Paths II (DP)

Questions.Text: Given a 2-d grid map of '1's (land) and '0's (water), count the number of islands. An island is surrounded by water and is formed by connecting adjacent lands horizontally or vertically. You may assume all four edges of the grid are all surrounded by water.
Questions.Name: Number of Islands (DFS/BFS)

Questions.Text: A 2d grid map of m rows and n columns is initially filled with water. We may perform an addLand operation which turns the water at position (row, col) into a land. Given a list of positions to operate, count the number of islands after each addLand operation. An island is surrounded by water and is formed by connecting adjacent lands horizontally or vertically. You may assume all four edges of the grid are all surrounded by water.
Questions.Name: Number of Islands II

Questions.Text: Given a 2D board containing 'X' and 'O', capture all regions surrounded by 'X'. A region is captured by flipping all 'O's into 'X's in that surrounded region.
Questions.Name: Surrounded Regions (BFS)

Questions.Text: Given a 2D binary matrix filled with 0's and 1's, find the largest rectangle containing all ones and return its area.
Questions.Name: Maximal Rectangle

Questions.Text: Given a 2D binary matrix filled with 0's and 1's, find the largest square containing all 1's and return its area.
Questions.Name: Maximal Square

Questions.Text: Given a 2D board and a word, find if the word exists in the grid.
Questions.Name: Word Search (DFS)

Questions.Text: Given a 2D board and a list of words from the dictionary, find all words in the board.
Questions.Name: Word Search II

Questions.Text: Given a positive integer n, break it into the sum of at least two positive integers and maximize the product of those integers. Return the maximum product you can get.
Questions.Name: Integer Break

Questions.Text: Given a 2D matrix matrix, find the sum of the elements inside the rectangle defined by its upper left corner (row1, col1) and lower right corner (row2, col2).
Questions.Name: Range Sum Query 2D – Immutable

Questions.Text: Given an integer matrix, find the length of the longest increasing path.
Questions.Name: Longest Increasing Path in a Matrix (DFS)

Questions.Text: You want to build a house on an empty land which reaches all buildings in the shortest amount of distance. You can only move up, down, left and right. You are given a 2D grid of values 0, 1 or 2, where:
Questions.Name: Shortest Distance from All Buildings

Questions.Text: Given a board with m by n cells, each cell has an initial state live (1) or dead (0). Each cell interacts with its eight neighbors (horizontal, vertical, diagonal) using the following four rules:
Questions.Name: Game of Life

Questions.Text: This post shows how to implement a stack by using an array.
Questions.Name: Implement a Stack Using an Array

Questions.Text: You are given two linked lists representing two non-negative numbers. The digits are stored in reverse order and each of their nodes contain a single digit. Add the two numbers and return it as a linked list.
Questions.Name: Add Two Numbers

Questions.Text: Given a linked list and a value x, partition it such that all nodes less than x come before nodes greater than or equal to x.

Questions.Text: Given a linked list, remove the nth node from the end of list and return its head.
Questions.Name: Remove Nth Node From End of List (Fast-Slow Pointers)

Questions.Text:
Implement the following operations of a stack using queues.
push(x) -- Push element x onto stack.
pop() -- Removes the element on top of the stack.
top() -- Get the top element.
empty() -- Return whether the stack is empty.
Questions.Name: Implement Stack using Queues

Questions.Text: Implement the following operations of a queue using stacks.

Questions.Name: Palindrome Linked List

Questions.Name: Delete Node in a Linked List

Questions.Text: Given a binary tree containing digits from 0-9 only, each root-to-leaf path could represent a number. Find the total sum of all root-to-leaf numbers.

Questions.Text: This is a classic interview question. Another similar problem is "merge k sorted lists".
Questions.Name: Merge k sorted arrays

Questions.Text: Merge k sorted linked lists and return it as one sorted list. Analyze and describe its complexity.
Questions.Name: Merge k Sorted Lists *

Questions.Text: Median is the middle value in an ordered integer list. If the size of the list is even, there is no middle value. So the median is the mean of the two middle value.
Questions.Name: Find Median from Data Stream

Questions.Text: Implement a trie with insert, search, and startsWith methods.
Questions.Name: Implement Trie (Prefix Tree)

Questions.Text: Design a data structure that supports the following two operations:
Questions.Name: Add and Search Word - Data structure design (DFS)

Questions.Text: Given an integer array nums, find the sum of the elements between indices i and j (i ≤ j), inclusive. The update(i, val) function modifies nums by updating the element at index i to val.
Questions.Name: Range Sum Query - Mutable

Questions.Name: The Skyline Problem

Questions.Text: LeetCode Problem:
Questions.Name: Clone Graph

Questions.Text: There are a total of n courses you have to take, labeled from 0 to n - 1. Some courses may have prerequisites, for example to take course 0 you have to first take course 1, which is expressed as a pair: [0,1]. Given the total number of courses and a list of prerequisite pairs, is it possible for you to finish all courses?
Questions.Name: Course Schedule (BFS/DFS)

Questions.Text: This is an extension of Course Schedule. This time a valid sequence of courses is required as output.
Questions.Name: Course Schedule II (BFS)

Questions.Text: Given a list of airline tickets represented by pairs of departure and arrival airports [from, to], reconstruct the itinerary in order. All of the tickets belong to a man who departs from JFK. Thus, the itinerary must begin with JFK.
Questions.Name: Reconstruct Itinerary

Questions.Text: Given n nodes labeled from 0 to n - 1 and a list of undirected edges (each edge is a pair of nodes), check if these edges form a valid tree.
Questions.Name: Graph Valid Tree

Questions.Text: While analyzing source code of a large number of open source Java projects, I found Java developers frequently sort in two ways. One is using the sort() method of Collections or Arrays, and the other is using sorted data structures, such as TreeMap and TreeSet.
Questions.Name: Java developers sort in practice

Questions.Text: LeetCode - Sort List:
Questions.Name: Mergesort

Questions.Text: Quicksort is a divide and conquer algorithm. It first divides a large list into two smaller sub-lists and then recursively sort the two sub-lists. If we want to sort an array without any extra space, quicksort is a good option. On average, time complexity is O(n log(n)).
Questions.Name: Quicksort

Questions.Text: Insertion Sort List:
Questions.Name: InsertionSort

Questions.Text: Given an unsorted array, find the maximum difference between the successive elements in its sorted form.
Questions.Name: Maximum Gap (Bucket Sort)

Questions.Text: Given an unsorted integer array, find the first missing positive integer. For example, given [1,2,0] return 3 and [3,4,-1,1] return 2.
Questions.Name: First Missing Positive (Bucket Sort)

Questions.Text: Given an array with n objects colored red, white or blue, sort them so that objects of the same color are adjacent, with the colors in the order red, white and blue.
Questions.Name: Sort Colors (Counting Sort)

Questions.Text: Given a string S and a string T, count the number of distinct subsequences of T in S.
Questions.Name: Distinct Subsequences Total

Questions.Text: Finding the longest palindromic substring is a classic problem of coding interview. This post summarizes 3 different solutions for this problem.
Questions.Name: Longest Palindromic Substring

Questions.Text: 1. Naive Approach
Questions.Name: Word Break

Questions.Text: Given a string s and a dictionary of words dict, add spaces in s to construct a sentence where each word is a valid dictionary word. Return all such possible sentences. For example, given s = "catsanddog", dict = ["cat", "cats", "and", "sand", "dog"], the solution is ["cats and dog", "cat sand dog"].
Questions.Name: Word Break II

Questions.Text: Find the contiguous subarray within an array (containing at least one number) which has the largest sum.
Questions.Name: Maximum Subarray

Questions.Text: Find the contiguous subarray within an array (containing at least one number) which has the largest product.
Questions.Name: Maximum Product Subarray

Questions.Text: Problem
Questions.Name: Palindrome Partitioning

Questions.Text: Given a string s, partition s such that every substring of the partition is a palindrome. Return the minimum cuts needed for a palindrome partitioning of s. For example, given s = "aab", return 1 since the palindrome partitioning ["aa","b"] could be produced using 1 cut.
Questions.Name: Palindrome Partitioning II

Questions.Text: You are a professional robber planning to rob houses along a street. Each house has a certain amount of money stashed, the only constraint stopping you from robbing each of them is that adjacent houses have security system connected and it will automatically contact the police if two adjacent houses were broken into on the same night.
Questions.Name: House Robber

Questions.Text: After robbing those houses on that street, the thief has found himself a new place for his thievery so that he will not get too much attention. This time, all houses at this place are arranged in a circle. That means the first house is the neighbor of the last one. Meanwhile, the security system for these houses remain the same as for those in the previous street.
Questions.Name: House Robber II

Questions.Text: The houses form a binary tree. If the root is robbed, its left and right can not be robbed.
Questions.Name: House Robber III

Questions.Text: Given an array of non-negative integers, you are initially positioned at the first index of the array. Each element in the array represents your maximum jump length at that position. Determine if you are able to reach the last index. For example: A = [2,3,1,1,4], return true. A = [3,2,1,0,4], return false.
Questions.Name: Jump Game

Questions.Text: Given an array of non-negative integers, you are initially positioned at the first index of the array. Each element in the array represents your maximum jump length at that position.
Questions.Name: Jump Game II

Questions.Text: Say you have an array for which the ith element is the price of a given stock on day i.
Questions.Name: Best Time to Buy and Sell Stock

Questions.Text: Say you have an array for which the ith element is the price of a given stock on day i.
Questions.Name: Best Time to Buy and Sell Stock II

Questions.Text: Say you have an array for which the ith element is the price of a given stock on day i.
Questions.Name: Best Time to Buy and Sell Stock III

Questions.Text: Problem
Questions.Name: Best Time to Buy and Sell Stock IV

Questions.Text: Example:
Questions.Name: Dungeon Game

Questions.Text: Given a m x n grid filled with non-negative numbers, find a path from top left to bottom right which minimizes the sum of all numbers along its path.
Questions.Name: Minimum Path Sum

Questions.Text: A robot is located at the top-left corner of a m x n grid. It can only move either down or right at any point in time. The robot is trying to reach the bottom-right corner of the grid.
Questions.Name: Unique Paths

Questions.Text: A message containing letters from A-Z is being encoded to numbers using the following mapping:
Questions.Name: Decode Ways

Questions.Text: The longest common subsequence (LCS) problem is the problem of finding the longest subsequence common to all sequences in a set of sequences (often just two sequences).
Questions.Name: Longest Common Subsequence

Questions.Text: In computer science, the longest common substring problem is to find the longest string that is a substring of two or more strings.
Questions.Name: Longest Common Substring

Questions.Text: Given an unsorted array of integers, find the length of longest increasing subsequence.
Questions.Name: Longest Increasing Subsequence

Questions.Text: You are given coins of different denominations and a total amount of money amount. Write a function to compute the fewest number of coins that you need to make up that amount. If that amount of money cannot be made up by any combination of the coins, return -1.
Questions.Name: Coin Change

Questions.Text: Given a positive integer n, find the least number of perfect square numbers (for example, 1, 4, 9, 16, ...) which sum to n.
Questions.Name: Perfect Squares

Questions.Text: The problem:
Questions.Name: Single Number

Questions.Text: Problem
Questions.Name: Single Number II

Questions.Text: Problem: Get maximum binary Gap.
Questions.Name: Maximum Binary Gap

Questions.Text: Problem
Questions.Name: Number of 1 Bits

Questions.Text: Problem
Questions.Name: Reverse Bits

Questions.Text: Problem
Questions.Name: Repeated DNA Sequences

Questions.Text: Given a range [m, n] where 0 <= m <= n <= 2147483647, return the bitwise AND of all numbers in this range, inclusive. For example, given the range [5, 7], you should return 4. Java Solution
Questions.Name: Bitwise AND of Numbers Range

Questions.Text: Given an integer, write a function to determine if it is a power of two.
Questions.Name: Power of Two

Questions.Text: Given a non negative integer number num. For every numbers i in the range 0 ≤ i ≤ num calculate the number of 1's in their binary representation and return them as an array.
Questions.Name: Counting Bits

Questions.Text: Given a string array words, find the maximum value of length(word[i]) * length(word[j]) where the two words do not share common letters. You may assume that each word will contain only lower case letters. If no such two words exist, return 0.
Questions.Name: Maximum Product of Word Lengths

Questions.Text: Given a collection of numbers, return all possible permutations.
Questions.Name: Permutations

Questions.Text: Given a collection of numbers that might contain duplicates, return all possible unique permutations.
Questions.Name: Permutations II

Questions.Text: The set [1,2,3,…,n] contains a total of n! unique permutations.
Questions.Name: Permutation Sequence

Questions.Text: Given n pairs of parentheses, write a function to generate all combinations of well-formed parentheses.
Questions.Name: Generate Parentheses

Questions.Text: Given a set of candidate numbers (C) and a target number (T), find all unique combinations in C where the candidate numbers sums to T. The same repeated number may be chosen from C unlimited number of times.
Questions.Name: Combination Sum (DFS)

Questions.Text: Given a collection of candidate numbers (C) and a target number (T), find all unique combinations in C where the candidate numbers sums to T. Each number in C may only be used ONCE in the combination.
Questions.Name: Combination Sum II (DFS)

Questions.Text: Find all possible combinations of k numbers that add up to a number n, given that only numbers from 1 to 9 can be used and each combination should be a unique set of numbers.
Questions.Name: Combination Sum III (DFS)

Questions.Text: Problem
Questions.Name: Combinations (DFS)

Questions.Text: Given a digit string, return all possible letter combinations that the number could represent. (Check out your cellphone to see the mappings) Input:Digit string "23", Output: ["ad", "ae", "af", "bd", "be", "bf", "cd", "ce", "cf"].
Questions.Name: Letter Combinations of a Phone Number (DFS)

Questions.Text: Given a string containing only digits, restore it by returning all possible valid IP address combinations.
Questions.Name: Restore IP Addresses

Questions.Text: LeetCode - Reverse Integer:
Questions.Name: Reverse Integer

Questions.Text: Determine whether an integer is a palindrome. Do this without extra space.
Questions.Name: Palindrome Number

Questions.Text: Problem:
Questions.Name: Pow(x,n)

Questions.Text: Note: 1) Elements in a subset must be in non-descending order. 2) The solution set must not contain duplicate subsets.
Questions.Name: Subsets

Questions.Text: Given a set of distinct integers, S, return all possible subsets.
Questions.Name: Subsets II

Questions.Text: Problem
Questions.Name: Fraction to Recurring Decimal

Questions.Text: Problem
Questions.Name: Excel Sheet Column Number

Questions.Text: Problem
Questions.Name: Excel Sheet Column Title

Questions.Text: Given an integer n, return the number of trailing zeroes in n!.
Questions.Name: Factorial Trailing Zeroes

Questions.Text: Write an algorithm to determine if a number is "happy".
Questions.Name: Happy Number

Questions.Text: Count the number of prime numbers less than a non-negative number, n
Questions.Name: Count Primes

Questions.Text: Given a non-negative number represented as an array of digits, plus one to the number. The digits are stored such that the most significant digit is at the head of the list.
Questions.Name: Plus One

Questions.Text: Divide two integers without using multiplication, division and mod operator. If it is overflow, return MAX_INT.
Questions.Name: Divide Two Integers

Questions.Text: Given two numbers represented as strings, return multiplication of the numbers as a string.
Questions.Name: Multiply Strings

Questions.Text: Given n points on a 2D plane, find the maximum number of points that lie on the same straight line.
Questions.Name: Max Points on a Line

Questions.Text: Given an array of n integers where n > 1, nums, return an array output such that output[i] is equal to the product of all the elements of nums except nums[i].
Questions.Name: Product of Array Except Self

Questions.Text: Given an integer, write a function to determine if it is a power of three.
Questions.Name: Power of Three

Questions.Text: Given a positive integer n, break it into the sum of at least two positive integers and maximize the product of those integers. Return the maximum product you can get.
Questions.Name: Integer Break

Questions.Text: Given an integer (signed 32 bits), write a function to check whether it is a power of 4.
Questions.Name: Power of Four

Questions.Text: Given a non-negative integer num, repeatedly add all its digits until the result has only one digit.
Questions.Name: Add Digits

Questions.Text: Write a program to check whether a given number is an ugly number. Ugly numbers are positive numbers whose prime factors only include 2, 3, 5. For example, 6, 8 are ugly while 14 is not ugly since it includes another prime factor 7. Note that 1 is typically treated as an ugly number.
Questions.Name: Ugly Number

Questions.Text: Analysis
Questions.Name: Self Crossing

Questions.Text: Given a sorted positive integer array nums and an integer n, add/patch elements to the array such that any number in range [1, n] inclusive can be formed by the sum of some elements in the array. Return the minimum number of patches required.
Questions.Name: Patching Array

Questions.Text: ou are playing the following Nim Game with your friend: There is a heap of stones on the table, each time one of you take turns to remove 1 to 3 stones. The one who removes the last stone will be the winner. You will take the first turn to remove the stones.
Questions.Name: Nim Game

Questions.Text: There are n bulbs that are initially off. You first turn on all the bulbs. Then, you turn off every second bulb. On the third round, you toggle every third bulb (turning on if it's off or turning off if it's on). For the ith round, you toggle every i bulb. For the nth round, you only toggle the last bulb. Find how many bulbs are on after n rounds.
Questions.Name: Bulb Switcher

Questions.Text: There is a fence with n posts, each post can be painted with one of the k colors. You have to paint all the posts such that no more than two adjacent fence posts have the same color. Return the total number of ways you can paint the fence.
Questions.Name: Pain Fence
